_accidents.OtherReleaseSource: Pressure relief valve on heater due to airline to PSV521 bullet flow control valve breaking an causing flow control valve to close
_accidents.CI_OtherType: Re-routed vent line from the PSV to storage tank rather than flare.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION & EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Neches Industrial Park, Inc. began operations in November 1995.  The terminal was purchased by Martin Midstream Partners LP in June of 2004 and renamed Neches Terminal.  Martin is committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  Toward meeting this commitment the facility has in place an accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Jefferson County Local Emergency Planning Committee, General Land Office, Coast Guard and any other state or Federal agencies in mitigating any release and minimizing the impact of the release to people and the environment.





REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED OR STORED

Martin stores and handles the following regulated substances:

Anhydrous Ammonia (CAS: 7664-41-7)

Storage Quantity:  89,000,000 lbs





USES:

Anhydrous Ammonia is stored at the facility, with the majority utilized for distribution to end users.  Shipment methods include bulk cargo trailers, rail, and barge.  A small portion of the ammonia is utilized for the on-site production of ammonium thiosulfate (ATS), which is considered part of the overall ammonia-PSM operations.  





WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

The worst-case scenario is based on the rupture of a 34,000-ton (short) aboveground ammonia storage tank.  EPA rules would not allow use of water for mitigation when calculating our worst-case scenario.  Martin believes that the endpoint distance of 25 miles would be significantly reduced, since the tank is near water.  The endpoint distance was concluded using off-site consequence analysis guidance.



The alternative release scenario is based upon the activation of a railcar pressure relief valve and was selected due to the f

requency of railcar loading operations.  The endpoint distance of 0.24 miles is based upon ALOHA program calculations; the residential population would not be affected by this scenario.





THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Martin complies with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA)'s Process Safety Management Program (PSM) rules, EPA's Chemical Accident Prevention Risk Management Plan (RMP) rules and with applicable state codes and regulations.  

Martin's commitment to have in place controls to eliminate the potential for a release include but in not limited to:



   ?  Construction of two Anhydrous Ammonia storage tanks meeting the requirements of ANSI K61.1 and API-620 code.  Ammonia is 

      stored (maintained) at -27-degF, to minimize initial flashing in the event of a tank release.



   ?  Emergency vents and relief valves on transfer lines are routed to a closed-loop system which is vented to a flare.  



   ?  Safety instrumentation which include operation related alarms and interlocks.  Tank pressures are monitored twenty-four hours 

      each day, seven days a week by site operators.  



   ?  Ammonia vapor detectors are in place to provide the earliest possible detection of an ammonia release



   ?  Mechanical Integrity program which includes an inspection program with the objective on ensuring the proper operation of 

      equipment.



   ?  A fixed camera system with a digital recording system that allows operators to continuously monitor the ammonia flare for 

      problems with may result in a release.  



   ?  Storage tanks and loading facilities equipped with automatic emergency block valves to minimize a release.  In addition



   ?  Fire monitors are strategically placed to mitigate the effects of a release of ammonia.



   ?  Work permits are used to control any hazardous work around the facility



   ?  Management ensures that all personnel have the required level of

process knowledge and experience.



   ?  The facility is equipped with an audible warning system with procedures in place to notify on-site personnel in the event of 

      an emergency.  In addition to the audible warning system t is tested weekly to insure it is operational.



   ?  The Neches Terminal continuously monitors weather conditions and utilizes predictive software (ALOHA) so that potential impact 

      zones can be predicted in the event of a release



The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary source.





EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Martin's employees are strongly encouraged to express views concerning accident prevention, operational procedures, and recommended improvements.  Employees are included in planning meetings and development of procedures for the facility.  





PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

Martin maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with the process.





PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

Martin conducts hazard analyses to identify potential hazards associated with our operations are identified and control implemented.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is "What If /Checklist".  The hazard analyses are performed by a team of qualified personnel with experience in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at least once every five years.





OPERATING PROCEDURES

Martin maintains written operating procedures that address various modes of operation, such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdowns, etc.  The information is reviewed regularly and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.





TRAINING

Martin has a training program to ensure employees are competent in the operations and procedures associated with the process.





MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

Martin has implemented documented

maintenance checks on process equipment to confirm proper operations.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.





MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

Written procedures are in place at the facility to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.





PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEWS

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modification in established processes are conducted as a regular practice.  The reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.





COMPLIANCE AUDIT

Martin conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  These audits are carried out at least every three years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.





INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

Martin promptly investigates any incident that resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of anhydrous ammonia.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All investigation reports are retained for a minimum of five years.





CONTRACTORS

The contractor safety program involves training and records keeping ensuring contractors are aware of process hazards and facility procedures.  





FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

During the past five (5) years the Neches Terminal has had five (5) releases, the most notable occu

rred on December 16, 2016, releasing approximately 613 pounds of Vapor from an improperly set replacement PSV.  This release had no health effects on personnel.  No releases affected facilities outside of the perimeter of the Neches Terminal.



Release Date    Quantity    Descriptions            Reason                            Distance to

(mm/dd/yy)    (lbs)        Area                for Leak                        Drop-Off (Y/N)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------                

10/21/14    175        Flare "U" Manifold        NH3 'Burpover' from maint. valve that was left open.    375 yds

12/16/16    613        RRC Loading Ops        PRV was labeled and set incorrectly.            7.3 yds



Any releases, even those below reportable quantity, were reported per air permit requirements.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has a written emergency action plan (ERP), in accordance with the OSHA PSM rules (29 CFR).  The ERP includes appropriate mechanisms for notifying emergency responders when there is need for a response.  Emergency Response personnel are trained in accordance with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.156 and emergency drills are conducted quarterly.  The facility is listed in the community ERP.  An Incident Command System structure is utilized.



Additionally the terminal is a U.S.  Coast Guard Maritime regulated facility.  With this in mind, the terminal participates in all local drills conducted by the Coast Guard and many times is used in an active role by having a simulated  ammonia released from the facility as a  primary part of the drill.  





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvement is an on-going process.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess and maintain safety conditions.  Martin has designated personnel to ensure the programs referenced in this Executive Summary are maintained.  Additionally the site has Environmental and Safety personnel to assist in these efforts.



In summary, the Neches Terminal is committed to

implementing controls necessary to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention and personnel training, as well as considering safety as one of the highest priorities in the installation, operation, and maintenance of facility processes, in the unlikely event that a release occurs.
